this stuff so I've pretty much covered
that and I went backwards okay there we
go so about a year ago or so one of our
customers came up to us and said okay we would like to know we would like for you
to tell us how many e-commerce websites existed in Latin America and they wanted
to see if they could and our first reaction was like okay so you guys are the biggest player in e-commerce in
Latin America and you actually don't know that number how does that work but
they're like we don't know and we talked to a lot of people in e-commerce and people were saying you know we have I
don't know how much fifty percent of the market 70 percent of market alike and we asked them okay so if you have 70
percent of the market what's the size of the size of the market how many companies are there like well actually we don't know and we're okay but and so
we started looking at how we could work in order to answer that question in order to provide them with that
information and they said okay so it's not only knowing how many websites are there but we actually want to
monitor them on a consistent basis because we want to see they had that they have this logo for the product that
they sell and we want to see how many people are using our logo how many people are using our products and how
you know this tracks over time and how it involves and so on and so we started
looking at the problem from different angles and it said okay so basically what we have to do is build a crawling process that actually visits and
monitors these websites and checks everything but we have to do that in a way that is cost effective and it's
pretty dynamic we needed to do that you know we started out thinking okay so
we're going to do this every three months and once we started looking at how the data behavior is we saw okay so
we actually need to do this every other week and not every three months and so
we started thinking about okay so cost-efficient scalable we needed all those those things and I said okay I
know how we're going to do this I'm going to get my laptop and run it over the weekend in my house and that didn't
work out very well and so he said okay so let's try in and build something a
little bit more robust than that so we grabbed a an old server that we had in
the back of the closet and that didn't work out and said okay let's talk to the
AWS guys we've been talking to them for some time and so and so we started looking at the
processing okay so what do we need to do this and we started trying out architectures and working on stuff and
seeing let's try to do this with databases let's try to do this in several different ways in it it wasn't
working out very well and then I started having these discussions and we started
learning okay so perhaps the best way to go about this and it was really interesting because we were in a meeting
with Adi and we left I mean we were discussing ideas and throwing ideas on the board and we left the meeting and I
turned to one of my colleagues and say okay you know maybe we should look at this sqs stuff and at the same time my
phone beeped and there was disaster mess from buddy saying you know you really I should really look at this sqs steps
just like okay so at least we're on the same page there and we started looking
at sqs and I started looking at how we can use sqs to really scale our process because we ended up using thousands and
thousands of spot instances running thousands and thousands of processes and once you start doing that you really
start hitting some limits that you don't see in the real world like there's a limit to the number of some of the
simultaneous connections that you can open up to two databases and this was actually applying to all databases limit
some connections to web services and we tried using standard web servers to synchronize stuff and it wasn't working
working out very well so we decided okay so sqs provider is a very efficient way
to orchestrate our entire process and a very efficient way to actually scale out this process to a massively right to do
all these thousands of images and so on and we also leveraged s3 in order to
store all the intermediate data that we need to store logs for the processes and so on and we really really use spot
instances we love them they keep our costs really low and they really help us out so after a lot of discussion and a
lot of coming and going this is the overall architecture that we ended up using so essentially what we have is an
Orchestrator which is that machine up there on the top which we call the maestro and that's a reserved instance
and that's running all the time and basically what it does is it initializes the process by uploading everything that
we need to crawl into a queue and that's what really gets the process going because from there we have a set of main
what we call the main workers which are different processes that run on spot instances there are going to be
consuming messages from the queue doing the what we call the basic crawl which
is essentially doing the get on the website loading that HTML code running
some basic processing on it and then we started chaining the process with additional queues in order to do
additional processing on each step so if I take a website and I identify it as an e-commerce website I'll ship it off to a
queue that's going to have another worker attached to it that's going to do some different work on it if I identify it as another type
of website I'm going to do something else with it so I'll put in a different cue and so on and at the end of the
whole process once we have the data set with the set of data that we need for each individual website we'll put it on
a final cue that's basically controlling the true put to the database so that we don't don't exceed maximum connections
or anything like that that's storing the data on a MongoDB cluster another very
interesting thing that we were able to do with sqs was to create a command and control queue which basically allows us
to command and control the entire process we have all of our different spot instances all of our different
worker instances listening to this queue and we set up sort of a broadcast system where the domain the orchestrator can
put a message on the queue in each instance we'll read that message and perform some action based on it and that
can be something as simple as reporting their status so that we know how far along a process is going without having
to go to the dashboard and seeing how many messages are in flight or still on
the queue or as complicated as halting the entire process sometimes as we were
doing this we started figuring out that there were times where we need to halt the entire process and go back a couple
steps or something like that and that queue allows us to send a message that after a few minutes every single
instance of it will have read it and will halt their processing and can even shut themselves down so we were able to
build a pretty interesting control structure relying entirely on the queue
which ensures that messages are read ensures that the messages are processed that we don't lose any messages along
the way give us all of the benefits that Arie told us about at the beginning so
we ended up creating a very interesting structure there and just to give you an
idea of message volumes that we handle this is this is actually from a couple
of maybe a couple of weeks ago or it's just it's a little bit old we've actually increased these numbers a
little bit but basically we run this process this is tire crawling process every week and the
whole process takes about 48 hours to run from start to finish we start off with roughly 10 million messages on our
initial queue and each message as its process may generate up to 10 or even
sometimes even more additional messages in order to do for us to do additional processing this once again this can be
as simple as performing some work on top of the stuff that we crawled or it can
be as complex as you know I need to crawl this again so let's add it back to the queue at the peak processing we
actually were now about 200,000 messages per second that we're processing from these cues so it's a pretty resource
intensive and we're really taxing the queues in terms of getting messages from them and processing these messages and
the leading them from the queues as we go along and so on and so on and the very interesting thing for us about sqs
is that it really gave us a lot of resiliency to this to this distributed process because if anything goes wrong
with one of our workers and for any chance and we're relying on spot instances so someone outbids is on the
spot instance and the spot analysis goes down or something goes wrong along the way the message will simply be put back
into the queue and we can process it we can make sure that someone else is going to pick up that message later on and
actively process it as we go along so that's a very useful feature for us to
have because it ensures that we we don't have to worry about you know was my
message actually processed did I actually do everything that I needed to do along the way in the process so it
really ensures that and for us at least the command and control queue is very interesting structure that we've been
leveraging on other products on other projects that we've been doing because it really allows us to adjust the
processing as we go along it can even be used as I was saying to shut down instances or to shut down some of the
workers inside an instance or to fire off new workers inside of an instance that's underused
we can really it allows us a very fine grain level of control about what's going on inside each
instance as we go along the process and it really gives us a lot more visibility
than simply looking at the dashboard and seeing how many messages are being processed at any given time so it allows
us to do that and it's been working very very well it's stopped working okay the
way it's just blinking red okay I'll
take it from there so in terms of results that we've been getting we've been as I said we've been
running this process since January so about 11 months now and we were actually
able to over the course of this time we've managed to process over three petabytes of data and we visited almost
a hundred billion different what not different but almost a hundred billion web pages a lot of times since we run it
weekly we'll visit the same pages over and over again but that's a lot of bit
that's a lot of pages and that's a lot of information to be stored we've relied on MongoDB to store the data it gave us
some flexibility that we didn't find in other solutions we will also leverage a
lot of AWS services in order to to control the MongoDB clusters that we need to process the data and so on and
so on but the most important thing for us is that we were actually able to answer to our client
how many e-commerce websites were there what they were doing which products they
were selling which services they were using we saw that we didn't need actually to limit ourselves only to
e-commerce websites and only to the service that our client was asking us to monitor but we could actually monitor

well today we're looking at all the websites in Latin America in terms of what kind of services they are
